answers.answer: Yes, you are at risk.  My mother lost her first child to it, but went on to have a healthly baby next (me), so don't get too worried.  I also developed preeclampsia with my pregnancy, but careful monitoring and deciding to induce 2 weeks early ended with my very healthy son.  First, your doctor should be monitoring your blood pressure (if this is difficult, use the blood pressure 'self-test' at the pharmacies).  If your BP is regularly high, make sure you see your doctor.  If you are swelling, put your self on bed-rest; as much as possible, elevate your feet - and I MEAN at every opportunity. If you are overweight, consider the possibility of gestational diabetes (this was my prob). Controlling my blood sugar and the steps I said above went a long way to having a pretty good preganancy.  It was only in the last week or so my BP shot up; then I was confined to bed rest (doctor's orders!  and incredibly boring after a day or so. only out of bed for the bathroom....).  Anyway, educate yourself and take steps to monitor yourself and ease the strain on your body. Good luck to you!

question: Two years ago I lost my first baby to Preeclampsia. During this time I had an excessive amount of swelling. I am currently 5 months with my second child and the excessive swelling has returned. So my question is: Is the excessive swelling that is occurring now a sign that I may be at risk for preeclampsia once again?
title: Preclampsia
